III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth is being bullied and abused by unknown person.
Investigation Interviews:
On 9/23/24 Complainant reported that Youth A believed no one
understood her and she wished she was never born. Youth A
reported she was being bullied and abused by an unknown
person. Youth A attempted to kill herself and failed, but she
wished she did end her life. It is unknown how Youth Attempted
suicide.
Complainant was contacted by phone on 9/24/24. Complainant
reported they did not have any additional information. The
information reported came from a note that Youth A wrote.
On 9/24/24 Foster Care Worker (FCW) was contacted by email.
FCW reported that Youth A had ongoing conflict with a peer in the
home, Youth B. FCW observed that both youth picked at each
other and got involved in each other’s “business”, which lead to
verbal aggression from both of them. FCW did not have any
concerns about the placement. FCW indicated Youth A had a
history of making complaints when she decided she wanted to
leave previous placements. FCW reported Youth A had a history
of suicide attempts and ideation.
On 9/25/24 Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility.
Youth A stated that she did not attempt to harm herself and was
not suicidal; she just wanted the bullying from Youth B to stop.
Youth A felt that the only way to get someone to listen was by
writing the journal entry, which triggered this investigation. Youth
A reported that she and Youth B did not get along. Youth A stated
the agency recently implemented a “separation order” as a safety
2

plan, where Youth A and Youth B could not be in the same room
together.
Youth A stated no staff were abusing her, although she did not like
how they talked to her at times. Youth A stated that staff usually
do not listen to her about issues with Youth B. Youth A recalled an
incident recently where Youth B punched her in the face, while
they were in the agency van. Youth A stated that staff intervened
and separated them. However, when Youth A later asked to press
charges, staff would not help her. Youth A then clarified that staff
called the police for her. However, because the incident happened
in the adjacent city, police informed Youth A she needed to go to
that precinct to file a report. Youth A stated she asked staff to take
her to the precinct, but they refused.
Youth A stated she was frustrated with staff not holding Youth B
accountable. Staff would never take privileges away from Youth B
and when Youth A would question staff, they would answer “mind
your business”. Youth A stated that staff told her to ignore Youth B
when she would say rude things. Overall, Youth A felt that staff
were showing favoritism to Youth B.
Youth A reported some additional concerns regarding her
placement. Youth A stated she was at an urgent care appointment
one day and missed lunch. When they returned to the house, staff
would not let her make food. However, staff let her make
something later. Youth A also reported she had food allergies and
staff did not always buy food she could eat. Lastly, Youth A stated
that staff yelled a lot.
DCWL Consultant completed an unannounced visit at the facility
on 9/26/24 and reported some concerns she received from youth.
Youth A reported she was afraid of Youth B and did not feel safe
at the facility. DCWL Consultant observed what she believed to be
staff not following policy related to phone and computer usage by
youth. Youth B was observed to use the phone outside of the
designated area and engaged in conversation that involved
yelling, screaming and profanity. Staff did not redirect her or
request that the youth end the call. Staff appeared to be
intimidated by Youth B. Youth B was also able to have a personal
computer and use it whenever she wanted. Staff stated they were
under the impression they could not regulate the computer as it
was provided by her foster care worker. DCWL Consultant was
unable to interview Youth B, as she went AWOL during the visit.
3

Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face on 10/7/24.
Chief Administrator reported there was no policy forbidding
phones or computers in the youth’s bedrooms. Youth B was
allowed to have her personal computer in her room. All youth were
able to use their school provided laptops until 9:00pm.
Chief Administrator reported there have not been any reported
problems with staff providing allergy safe foods for Youth A.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face on 10/7/24. Staff 1 reported
she is the program manager and visits the house 3-4 times per
week. Staff 1 stated the current separation order between Youth A
and Youth B has been helpful. However, both youth are stubborn
and contribute to issues. Staff 1 did not feel it was a one-sided
situation where Youth B was bullying Youth A. Youth B did pick on
Youth A, but Youth A also instigated and agitated Youth B. Youth
A has very set beliefs in how she thinks things should be and if
peers do not do it that way, she criticizes them and tries to have
staff take her side. This aggravates Youth B and other peers in the
house.
Staff 1 reported there is not a policy regarding youth using
personal computers. However, staff ask youth to turn school
computers in to staff at 9:00pm. Staff 1 confirmed that Youth B
had a personal computer, provided by her caseworker. Youth B
was able to use the computer in her room. Staff 1 stated that staff
do not usually take the computer for disciplinary action, but they
could. Typically, Youth B would receive a fine or lose the
opportunity for an outing.
Fines in the home are imposed when youth use profanity towards
staff, refuse to go to school, or refuse to do chores. Fines are
deducted from the youth’s weekly allowance or shopping money.
Staff 1 reported that staff and youth plan meals and cook together.
If a youth does not like the prepared meal, they can eat leftovers
or make something else. If a youth refused dinner, they could
make something later when they are hungry. Although that would
typically be something quick and easy, so youth are not up
cooking a full meal late at night. Staff 1 has not witnessed Youth A
to miss any meals due to appointments or being unable to eat the
meal because of food allergy. Staff 1 stated all of the staff are
aware of Youth A’s food allergies, as it is posted in the kitchen.
Staff ensure that safe groceries are purchased for everyone.
Staff 1 was not present for the incident of Youth B punching Youth
A in the van. Staff 1 was informed by other staff that after
speaking with police, Youth A declined to go to the police
department to file a report.
4

Staff 1 stated she never observed staff yell or swear at youth.
Staff 1 did not observed staff to be on their phones or ignoring
youth. Staff 1 did not witness any favoritism of certain youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face on 10/7/24. Staff 2 is the
case manager for Youth A. Staff 2 stated the separation
agreement for Youth A and Youth B minimized negative
interactions between youth. Staff 2 stated both youth are strong
personalities, and they are frequently verbally aggressive toward
one another.
Staff 2 was not present for the incident in the van. However, she
was told by other staff that Youth B punched Youth A; Youth A
was offered an opportunity to file a police report but declined.
Regarding fines, youth are fined for things such as refusing to do
chores or refusing to go to school. Fines are taken from their
weekly allowance. Their money is then set aside and not given to
them to spend on outings. Staff also use positive reinforcement,
such as earning points toward rewards.
Staff 2 stated that youth cook with staff and plan meals together.
Youth can make an alternate meal if they want. If youth refuse a
meal, they are able to make something later. Sometimes youth
refuse when they do not like what is available. Staff 2 stated all
staff are aware of youth allergies. Staff 2 never witnessed any
youth to go without a meal.
Staff 2 reported youth have time limits on their school computers
and must turn them in at 9:00pm. However, Youth B has a
personal computer provided by her DHHS worker. Youth B signed
a technology use policy indicating she cannot use it during
sleeping hours, but she can have it freely during the day. Youth B
is able to use the computer in her room. Youth B may lose the
privilege of her computer if she abuses it.
Staff 2 did not witness any staff yelling or swearing at youth.
However, staff do raise their voices when youth are yelling or not
listening. Staff 2 indicated house staff could be gentler with
wording at times. Staff 2 stated she observed all youth to be
treated the same by staff. In her opinion, no youth have received
preferential treatment.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face on 10/7/24. Staff 3 stated she
typically works afternoons and helps youth with dinner and chores.
Staff 3 acknowledged that the youth can be disrespectful at times
and not do what they are asked. Youth can be fined for that
5

behavior. Often the youth will say “I don’t care” regarding the
fines, then continue their behavior. Youth A frequently does this.
Staff often redirect Youth A as she threatens and talks about staff
and peers, which causes conflict. Youth A would also mimic
people to irritate them. Staff 3 stated in her opinion Youth A and
Youth B are equally aggressive with one another. Youth A will
often argue and disagree with people and tell them she hates
everyone there. Staff try to keep the peace between Youth A and
Youth B, and often kept them separated. Staff 3 stated she would
typically talk with Youth A to get down to the bottom of the issue
and look for resolution. Staff 3 indicated they felt that staff do not
have a lot of options to address youth behavior, other than the fine
system. The system does not always work well, as youth do not
care about the fines.
Staff 3 stated she was not present when Youth A allegedly missed
lunch after an urgent care visit. Staff 3 stated that refusal forms
are completed when youth refuse a meal. Staff 3 observed that
Youth A would sometimes refuse her meals, but then ask for
cookies or something sweet. Staff would say no but tell Youth A
she could have something else for dinner. Staff 3 has not
observed a time that Youth A was unable to eat due to food
allergies. Staff understand Youth A’s food allergies and purchase
safe foods for her.
Staff 3 reported the youth rarely want to do activities or play
games. Youth typically want to use their computers in their down
time. Youth are able to use computers until 9:00pm. Youth A and
Youth B are able to do schoolwork in their rooms to keep them
separated. Youth B is also able to use her personal computer in
her room.
Staff 3 has not observed any staff yelling or swearing at youth.
Staff 3 felt that other staff handle conflict well. However, they
sometimes feel powerless as there are not consequences for
youth behavior.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face on 10/7/24. Staff 4 was
witness to incidents between Youth A and Youth B. Staff 4 stated
things seemed to have calmed down after the separation plan was
implemented.
Staff 4 was present during the incident in the van and reported it
began when Youth A was talking to Staff 7, and Youth B told her
to be quiet. Youth B then grabbed Youth A, there was some
pushing and Youth B punched Youth A. The van pulled over and
staff separated the youth into the front and back of the van and
6

spoke with them to calm them down. One staff moved to the back
seat to ensure there were no further incidents. When they arrived
at the house staff helped Youth A call the police. The police came
to the house and after hearing what happened advised her to file a
report in the adjacent city where the incident occurred. Youth A
decided not to file a report. Staff 4 and other staff offered to take
her to the police station, but she declined.
Regarding fines, there is a list of fines available to the girls, so
they know what the consequences are for certain behavior. Youth
lose privileges, allowance money, outings, or computer time. Staff
4 stated this system works sometimes, but not always. Often
youth are indifferent to losing these items. Youth B has a personal
computer that she is allowed to use in her room and at any time.
Staff do not feel they are able to remove this item as discipline,
due to it being something her DHHS worker provided. Staff stated
all youth are not allowed to use their school computers past
9:00pm and can sometimes use them in their bedrooms with staff
approval.
Staff 4 has not observed any staff to yell or swear at youth.
Staff 4 stated that staff and youth cook together. There is a list of
food allergies in the kitchen, which everyone is aware of and
follows. Staff 4 never observed a time that Youth A went without a
meal. Youth are required to sign a refusal form if they do not want
what is made. However, youth sometimes refuse to sign. If youth
do not want the meal that is made, they are able to make
something else.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face on 10/7/24. Staff 5 reported
they were not present for the incident in the van. However, Staff 5
witnessed Youth A and Youth B to argue “about everything” and
get involved in one another’s conversations to annoy each other.
Staff 5 never heard Youth A ask to file a police report against
Youth B.
Staff 5 reported youth are warned before receiving a fine for
profanity or being disrespectful. Some staff give more warnings
than others. Fines and removing privileges are sometimes
effective, but often the youth are not responsive.
Youth are allowed to use their school computers from 3-9:00PM.
There is a house computer they are also able to use at assigned
times. Youth can only have their laptops in their bedrooms when
approved by staff. There is not a specific policy about it. Youth B
is currently allowed to have her personal computer in her room.
7

Staff 5 has not observed any staff to yell, swear, or appear overly
frustrated with youth.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face on 10/7/24. Staff 6 stated
Youth A and Youth B often do not see eye to eye and argue with
one another. Youth A typically tried to avoid Youth B. Staff 6
stated the new separation plan has helped. However, Youth A
follows it better than Youth B. Staff 6 reported they do their best
to keep all of the youth safe. Staff 6 stated they spend a lot of time
listening to youth’s concerns and advocating when needed or
giving them suggestions on how to handle situations.
Staff 6 was not present for the incident in the van. Staff 6 never
heard Youth A request to go to the police station. Staff 6 recalled
hearing another staff say they offered to take Youth A. Staff 6
could not recall which staff said that.
Consequences in the home include removal of privileges such as
outings and computer times. Sometimes youth are fined and lose
some of their spending money for shopping trips. Youth are also
given incentives for good behavior such as favorite snacks,
sensory toys, or other things they like. Staff 6 indicated they are
not able to take Youth B’s computer away, due to it being a gift
from her DHHS worker. Staff 6 stated this caused issues between
the youth as they felt Youth B was favored and did not have
consequences when in trouble. Youth could use their school
computers until 9:00PM. Youth were allowed to use the computer
in their bedroom as approved by staff.
Staff 6 did not witness any staff yelling, swearing, or angry with
any youth. Staff 6 did not witness Youth A to miss any meals or be
denied the ability to make food for herself.
Staff 7 was interviewed face-to-face on 10/7/24. Staff 7 was
aware of the separation order and felt that it seemed to have
improved things.
Staff 7 reported she was in the van and saw Youth B punch Youth
A. This occurred after there was a verbal exchange between the
two. Law enforcement was called and stated they could not take a
report, because it happened in another city, while in a moving
vehicle. Youth A needed to go to the adjacent city’s police
department to file the report. Youth A told Staff 7 that she did not
want to do that. Youth A never asked to go to the police station
after that.
Staff 7 stated fines are most often imposed with youth when they
refuse to do tasks or curse at staff. Staff would typically give a
8

warning, but sometimes the youth would not correct their
behavior. Youth would also lose certain activities or outings at
times. Staff 7 felt that youth were disciplined equally. Although
Staff 7 was aware Youth B’s computer made the other youth feel
she was given favors. Youth B had a personal computer, which
staff were not allowed to take from her. Youth B was able to use
the computer in her room. The agency did not have a policy about
it specifically. Generally, youth could use their computers in their
room with staff approval. Computers were turned in to staff at
9:00PM. There was also a home computer that youth can sign up
for a certain time slot.
Staff 7 did not witness Youth A miss a meal at any time. Youth
and staff plan and cook meals together. Staff are aware of
allergies in the home and ensure there is something everyone can
eat. If a youth does not want the meal, they are able to make
something else.
Staff 7 never witnessed any staff to yell, swear at, or appear
overly frustrated with youth.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed by video call on
10/11/24. FCW reported that Youth A sometimes interprets
something to be yelling when it’s not. This has happened at
several previous placements. FCW stated that Youth A told her
she was not suicidal, but she knew what to say to get someone’s
attention. Youth A attends therapy and medication reviews
regularly. Youth A has complained about Youth B in the past and
was encouraged to use her coping skills. FCW indicated the
separation plan seems to have helped to keep Youth A and Youth
B from bothering one another. FCW expressed that Youth A does
not like her placement and wants to go to independent living.
Youth B could not be interviewed as she was not present when
initial interviews were completed. Youth B then left the program.
Unsuccessful attempts were made to contact Youth B at her
relative placement on 11/14/24 and 11/18/24
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face on 11/14/24. Youth C
reported that Youth A and Youth B often did not get along. Youth
C was present in the van when Youth B punched Youth A. Staff
immediately pulled over and separated the youth. Youth C
recalled that Youth A asked to call the police. However, Youth C
was unsure if that call happened. Youth C never heard Youth A
request to go to the police station or file a report.
9

Youth C stated she never witnessed Youth A to be denied a meal.
If youth miss a meal due to an appointment, they are able to make
something for themselves. Youth C stated staff do a really good
job of meal planning to follow the food allergies in the home.
Youth C stated that staff are strict and will fine them for not
following rules, or for being disrespectful. Youth C stated she has
not heard staff be rude or disrespectful to youth. Staff do not
spend a lot of time on their phones and are attentive to the youth.
Youth C did not feel that any youth are favored more than others.
However, she did note that Youth B was able to keep her
computer even when in trouble. Youth C stated that Youth B could
be on her computer whenever she wanted. All youth were able to
use their computers until about 9:00PM. Some youth were able to
use computers in their bedrooms with staff permission.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face on 11/14/24. Youth D
reported she had never observed Youth A to be denied a meal.
Youth and staff cook together. If a youth does not like the planned
meal, they are able to make something for themselves. Youth D
stated that staff do a good job following the food allergy
guidelines. Although, she recalled one time staff bought bread that
had sesame in it, which Youth A could not have. Youth A was
unable to make a sandwich. However, there was other food
available.
Youth D stated that youth can be fined for being disrespectful or
refusing to do chores. Youth D indicated staff were fair with fines
and did not seem to favor one youth over another. Youth D did not
feel that staff were on their phones often. Staff paid attention to
and socialized with youth.
In addition to fines, youth would lose privileges at times, such as
outings or computer time. Youth D recalled that Youth B never lost
her computer due to bad behavior, which seemed unfair.
However, Youth D acknowledged she did not know Youth B’s
case plan or what staff knew about the situation and tried to stay
out of it. Youth D stated they are able to use their computers in the
living room. Some youth are able to use them in their bedrooms,
such as Youth A and Youth B, due to staff trying to keep them
separated.
Youth D was not present for the incident in the van and did not
have any knowledge of police involvement. Youth D never heard
Youth A request to go to the police station or file a report.
10

Documents Reviewed:
• Incident report dated 9/23/24, authored by Staff 2. Youth A
left a note for a teacher indicating she tried to hurt herself
on 9/22/24 and did not feel safe. Youth A was taken to the
hospital for evaluation and kept overnight. Youth A
expressed to Staff 2 that she “misworded” the point she
was trying to get across in the letter.
• Safety plan dated 9/25/24, authored by Staff 2. Youth A
and Youth B will have different mealtimes and use different
restrooms in the home to avoid contact.
• A log of fines from June, July, and August 2024 were
reviewed. All youth were consistently fined for arguing,
threatening, refusing school, sneaking out, damaging
property, inappropriate computer usage, and not following
rules. There did not appear to be any favoritism to one
youth.
• A food allergy sign was posted in the kitchen of the facility,
identifying the food allergies for Youth A. Allergy compliant
food items were observed in the kitchen.
Analysis Based on interviews with staff and youth, no violation was found.
There was no information to support the allegation that Youth A
was being bullied and abused. While there were instances of
Youth A and Youth B having altercations, there was no indication
that staff failed to address these issues.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Technical assistance was provided to the agency regarding
behavior management strategies. Most staff indicated the fine
system is not effective. Staff expressed frustration over not having
effective behavior management strategies to address defiant and
disruptive behaviors. Staff also expressed confusion regarding
Youth A’s computer and their ability to remove it as a disciplinary
measure. Additional training for staff regarding behavior
management was encouraged.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
